msgSnippet: Vincent, I did not mean to offend you or complain about J2EEUnit versus other implementations, I think you made a great tool and I am grateful to you for this.

To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: Confused about J2EEUnit, JunitEE and JUnitServlet
Date: Thu, 1 Feb 2001 19:00:06 +0100 
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2650.21)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
From: "MARZIOU,GAEL (HP-France,ex1)" <gael_marziou@...>

Vincent,

I did not mean to offend you or complain about J2EEUnit versus other
implementations, I think you made a great tool and I am grateful to you for
this.
Whether someone find a tool easy to learn depends on lot of things including
user's own skills.
I would say that it may depend also on how you work, when running unit tests
that fail I like to use the debugger.
Most of the time I debug servlets using Tomcat from JBuilder 4 and in this
specific environment I found it easier to debug the server side directly
than debugging on top of an extra client side.
This said, our application server in production is not Tomcat and so your
client/server approach is very valuable to run the tests automatically in
our production environment.

Your idea of combining both approaches by providing 2 servlets is a good one
for me, I already started writing something like that by starting from
JunitEE servlet code.
What is currently missing is support for the extra methods beginXXX() and
endXXX() that are required by J2EEUnit and that are really useful. With
this, test cases could be run in both ways.

I like your explanation about the assumptions you made, to me it is
something that I did not really catch when reading the documentation, maybe
it should be even part of the introduction.

Thanks,

Gael
subject: RE: [junit] Re: Confused about J2EEUnit, JunitEE and JUnitServlet
